title: 1408-I
statement: I. Bitwise Magictime limit per test6 secondsmemory limit per test256 megabytesinputstandard inputoutputstandard outputYou are given a positive integer $$$k$$$ and an array $$$a_1, a_2, \\ldots, a_n$$$ of non-negative distinct integers not smaller than $$$k$$$ and not greater than $$$2^c-1$$$.In each of the next $$$k$$$ seconds, one element is chosen randomly equiprobably out of all $$$n$$$ elements and decreased by $$$1$$$.For each integer $$$x$$$, $$$0 \\leq x \\leq 2^c - 1$$$, you need to find the probability that in the end the bitwise XOR of all elements of the array is equal to $$$x$$$.Each of these values can be represented as an irreducible fraction $$$\\frac{p}{q}$$$, and you need to find the value of $$$p \\cdot q^{-1}$$$ modulo $$$998\\,244\\,353$$$.InputThe first line of input contains three integers $$$n, k, c$$$ ($$$1 \\leq n \\leq (2^c - k)$$$, $$$1 \\leq k \\leq 16$$$, $$$1 \\leq c \\leq 16$$$).The second line contains $$$n$$$ distinct integers $$$a_1, a_2, \\ldots, a_n$$$ ($$$k \\leq a_i \\leq 2^c-1$$$).OutputPrint $$$2^c$$$ integers: the probability that the bitwise XOR is equal to $$$x$$$ in the end for $$$x$$$ in $$$\\{0, 1, \\ldots, 2^c-1\\}$$$ modulo $$$998\\,244\\,353$$$.ExampleInput4 1 3 1 2 3 4Output0 0 0 748683265 0 499122177 0 748683265

processed.result: You have a list of distinct numbers. Over a set number of steps, each number in the list is randomly decreased by 1.  You need to calculate the probability that the sum of all the numbers in the list (using the bitwise XOR operation) will equal each possible number from 0 to a given limit.

You are given a positive integer $k$ and an array of $n$ distinct non-negative integers, $a_1, a_2, ..., a_n$, where each integer is at least $k$ and less than or equal to $2^c - 1$.

Over the next $k$ seconds, one element from the array is randomly chosen and decreased by 1 in each second.  

For each integer $x$ from 0 to $2^c - 1$, find the probability that the bitwise XOR of all the elements in the array will equal $x$ after $k$ seconds.

Each probability can be represented as a fraction $p/q$. You need to find the value of $p \cdot q^{-1}$ modulo $998244353$. 



Let me know if you'd like me to elaborate on any part of the problem!
